relationships.notes: Leaves his nets at Jesus’s call and is among the earliest disciples to remain with him after John the Baptist’s witness.
Identified as Simon Peter’s brother who brings him to Jesus and shares household scenes in Capernaum.
Works with Philip to bring seekers to Jesus, from Nathanael near Bethsaida to Greeks who request an audience.
Appears with Peter, James, and John on the Mount of Olives questioning Jesus about Jerusalem’s fate, reflecting participation in the leadership core.

traits.call_and_vocation: Introduced as a fisherman by the Sea of Galilee whom Jesus calls, together with his brother Simon, to become a fisher of people.
traits.relationship_to_peter: Consistently identified in relation to Simon, appearing with him at their shared house and in the list of the Twelve.
traits.role_among_twelve: Named among the Twelve but given little individual characterization beyond being part of the foundational group.
traits.participation_in_apocalyptic_discourse: Included among the four disciples who privately question Jesus about the destruction of the temple and the end, giving him a place on the inner edge of the circle.
traits.narrative_profile: Functions mainly as a background member of the core disciples, with no independent speeches or actions highlighted apart from group scenes.

traits.call_and_vocation: Portrayed as a fisherman in Galilee called along with his brother Simon while casting their net, immediately leaving their work to follow Jesus.
traits.relationship_to_peter: Introduced as the brother of Simon who is called Peter, with Peter clearly foregrounded as the more prominent figure.
traits.role_among_twelve: Listed among the first four in the roster of the Twelve, pairing him with Peter but without elaborating a distinct personal role.
traits.narrative_profile: Appears only in calling and list material, with Matthew otherwise focusing on Peter and the larger group rather than Andrew individually.

traits.role_among_twelve: Named in the formal selection of the Twelve as one of those whom Jesus designates apostles.
traits.relationship_to_peter: Identified as the brother of Simon Peter, linked to him in family terms rather than by independent activity.
traits.narrative_profile: Given no individual actions or dialogue and absent from Luke’s call narrative, indicating a strongly collective presentation of his role.
traits.naming_and_order: Placed early in the list of apostles, maintaining his association with Peter and the core leadership while still remaining a minor figure.

traits.initial_call_and_discipleship: Introduced as one of the first disciples, initially a follower of John the Baptist who, after hearing John’s testimony, follows Jesus.
traits.relationship_to_peter: Explicitly portrayed as Simon Peter’s brother who brings Simon to Jesus and is associated with Bethsaida, their shared hometown.
traits.mediator_and_recruiter: Regularly functions as an intermediary who brings others to Jesus, including his brother and later in cooperation with Philip regarding Greeks who wish to see Jesus.
traits.role_in_sign_stories: Appears in the feeding narrative by pointing out the boy with loaves and fish, framing the sign through his practical yet limited perspective.
traits.narrative_profile: Receives more individual characterization than in the Synoptics as an early and active witness who facilitates access to Jesus, though still overshadowed by Peter.

traits.presence_in_early_community: Listed among the apostles gathered in Jerusalem after the ascension, participating in the praying community awaiting the promised Spirit.
traits.apostolic_status: Counted as one of the core witnesses to Jesus’s ministry, death, and resurrection, forming part of the foundational apostolic group.
traits.narrative_silence: Receives no individual stories, speeches, or missionary episodes, reflecting Acts’ focus on Peter, John, Stephen, Philip, and Paul instead.
